channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Response to Thomas L. Friedman’s ‘Letter’ to President Xi
item.description: Global Times, a newspaper belonging to the flagship People’s Daily, has responded with apparent frankness to a column by Thomas L. Friedman, who warned against expelling Western journalists for their reporting on China.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Global Times said that Thomas L. Friedman was out of touch with China's security concerns.

item.title: Rodman to Return to North Korea Amid Political Upheaval
item.description: Dennis Rodman’s trip to North Korea to help train the country’s basketball stars has not been disrupted by the political convulsions there.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Account Says U.S. Ship Was Warned Away From Aircraft Carrier
item.description: China has offered little comment on a reported near collision at sea, although one Chinese media account says the United States Navy had been warned to move away from China’s new aircraft carrier
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: India Ink: Radio Station for Gay Indians Faces Uphill Battle to Draw Listeners
item.description: The mission of Q Radio of Bangalore, which is to serve the L.G.B.T. community, is complicated by the Supreme Court ruling that makes homosexuality illegal.
item.dc:creator: By RAKSHA KUMAR
item.media:description: The Q Radio station in Bangalore, Karnataka.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Amid China’s Bad Air, a Reminder That Smoking Still Kills
item.description: China has about 350 million smokers, and despite efforts to reduce consumption, tobacco is still widely consumed with about half of adult males smoking regularly, according to surveys.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoking has been cited as a key factor in the growing number of deaths from lung cancer in China.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Rural Women Stage Innovative Protest for Equality
item.description: Farming women gathered outside a provincial government headquarters and formed a human pyramid to highlight what they say is the widespread deprivation of their economic and other rights.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Women formed a human pyramid in front of the Zhejiang Provincial Government office in Hangzhou last week calling for equal economic rights.

item.title: India Ink: Where Dance and Textiles Meet
item.description: A new book by the New York photographer Briana Blasko, ‘Dance of the Weave,’ captures Indian dancers’ interaction with fabric through movement.
item.dc:creator: By BRIANA BLASKO

item.title: Rodman Headed to North Korea Again Despite Turmoil
item.description: The former basketball star Dennis Rodman, who befriended the nation’s leader, Kim Jong-un, was due to arrive Thursday to train its top players.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: South Korean Leader Warns of Possible ‘Provocations’ From North
item.description: Citing uncertainty about the North Korean regime following a dramatic purge, President Park Geun-hye ordered the military and police to step up their vigilance.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: North Koreans left flowers at the base of statues of the late leaders Kim Il-sung and Kim Jong-il in Pyongyang, Monday, the eve of the second anniversary of the death of Kim Jong-il.

item.title: Sports Briefing | Boxing: Klitschko Vacates Boxing Title
item.description: Vitali Klitschko vacated his World Boxing Council heavyweight title Monday and retired from boxing to concentrate on Ukrainian politics and his role as an opposition leader.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: London Journal: Growth Spurt Creates Alarm Over the House of (Many) Lords
item.description: After the latest influx this summer, the House of Lords has 836 members, and 781 of them have the right to revise or delay legislation, question ministers and take part in debates.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A statue of Richard the Lionheart near the peers entrance to Parliament.

item.title: A Political Deal in a Deeply Divided Tunisia as Islamists Agree to Yield Power
item.description: The deal between longtime enemies among the Islamists and the secular old guard aims to put in place an independent caretaker government until new elections next year.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rachid Ghannouchi, the leader of the Islamist party Ennahda.

item.title: Rocky Start in Promoting New Charter for Egypt
item.description: A campaign to win support for Egypt’s draft Constitution got off to an awkward start in Cairo on Sunday when observers noted several errors on a large banner promoting what is intended to become the nation’s charter.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY and MAYY EL SHEIKH

item.title: Unease as an Opposition Party Stands Out in Ukraine’s Protests
item.description: Marginalized before the protests, Svoboda is benefiting from them and its role has grown, though groups that monitor hate speech have criticized the party in the past.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators this week in Kiev, Ukraine, practiced defending their barricades from riot police officers. As the uprising has unfolded, the role of the nationalist party Svoboda has grown.

item.title: Bolivian Jail, an Actor’s Help and Now a Return to New York
item.description: Jacob Ostreicher, a Brooklyn flooring contractor who went to Bolivia to seek his fortune in rice farming but ended up being accused of laundering drug money, has been spirited out of the country, an assemblyman said.
item.dc:creator: By JOSEPH BERGER

item.title: Putin Is Expected to Offer Ukraine a Financial Lifeline
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia will meet Tuesday with Ukraine’s embattled president, Viktor F. Yanukovich, but officials said the possibility of Ukraine joining Russia’s customs union would not be discussed.
item.category: Customs Union of Russia, Belarus and Kazakhstan
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers guarded barricades in Independence Square in Kiev, Ukraine on Monday.

item.title: U.S.-Germany Intelligence Partnership Falters Over Spying
item.description: As President Obama considers his options on the surveillance of allies, damage to the United States’ relationship with Germany has proved difficult to repair.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel and President Obama in 2011. Their relationship has been severely tested in recent months.

item.title: Pope Replaces Conservative U.S. Cardinal on Influential Vatican Committee
item.description: Pope Francis, in naming bishops to a powerful Vatican committee, replaced a conservative American cardinal with another American considered more of a moderate on social issues.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY and JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: E.U. Pledges Aid for Mideast Peace
item.description: The European Union will provide “an unprecedented package of European political, economic and security support” to the Israelis and Palestinians if they reach a permanent peace deal, the union said in a statement.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Aid Challenge in Syria Mounts for U.N. Official
item.description: Some rights advocates say Valerie Amos, the United Nations relief coordinator, has been too patient with the Syrian government in pushing for access to areas in need.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Valerie Amos, the top United Nations relief official. The Syria crisis demands much of her time.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Regulations Will Increase Commercialization of Wild Animals, Experts Say
item.description: Proposed new state regulations will increase the exploitation of wild animals for commercial use and in circuses, animal rights advocates and academics say.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A macaque is chained to a wall in Suzhou to strengthen its legs for a circus performance.

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: 4 Die in North Caucasus Raid
item.description: Members of Russia’s security services killed four men suspected of being militants when they stormed an apartment building after a tense overnight standoff in the North Caucasus region.
item.dc:creator: By PATRICK REEVELL

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Ex-Official Released on Bail
item.description: Lalu Prasad, a once-powerful political leader from northern India, emerged from jail on Monday after spending more than two months behind bars on corruption charges.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR

item.title: Syria Activists Say Dozens Killed in Aleppo Air Assault
item.description: Reports by the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights and others said helicopters dropped barrels filled with TNT and shrapnel on 13 neighborhoods.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MOHAMMAD GHANNAM and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: The aftermath of an airstrike on a rebel area of Aleppo on Sunday.

item.title: President Says a Coup Failed in South Sudan
item.description: President Salva Kiir said that soldiers loyal to the former vice president had tried to orchestrate a coup but that his government was firmly in control.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH
item.media:description: President Salva Kiir of South Sudan said Monday in a televised address to the nation that the military had foiled a coup.
